nodes.text: Machine learning can provide novel insights and opportunities to improve reliability engineering and safety, by extracting more accurate patterns from degradation, accident, and telemetry datasets to support better decision-making and accident prevention
ML is organized into major categories relevant for reliability and safety: supervised, unsupervised, semi-supervised, and reinforcement learning
ML can tease out more accurate insights from accident, degradation, and survival datasets than traditional analysis tools, enabling better-informed decisions and more effective accident prevention
Supervised learning is widely used in reliability and safety for regression (e.g., remaining useful life estimation) and classification (e.g., fault detection and identification)

Regression methods applied include support vector regression, Gaussian process regression (kriging), and deep neural networks; these have been used for RUL and degradation prediction across batteries, bearings, engines, turbines and structural surrogate modeling

Classification and supervised models (decision trees, SVM, random forest, DNN/CNN/LSTM) have demonstrated improved fault detection, screening, and health-state classification in engines, bearings, transformers, wind turbines and software systems

Unsupervised learning (clustering, anomaly detection) is applied to discover structure and detect unexpected behavior without labels and is useful for degradation-mode mining, damage classification, and early fault detection

Unsupervised and hybrid deep approaches (autoencoders, self-organizing maps, Normal Behavior Models) and distance-metric clustering have been used for anomaly detection and monitoring in wind turbines, flight data, gas turbines and induction motors

Semi-supervised learning leverages abundant unlabeled data with few labels (graph-based methods, ladder networks, VAEs, co-training) to improve fault detection and RUL estimation when labeled failures are scarce

Reinforcement learning and deep reinforcement learning can optimize inspection, maintenance scheduling and sampling in large state/action problems; Safe Reinforcement Learning is required to respect safety constraints during learning

Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) and Support Vector methods are methodological options offering uncertainty quantification (GPR) or robustness to noise (SVM/SVR), useful for surrogate modeling and probabilistic reliability analysis

Deep learning (CNN, RNN, LSTM, autoencoders, GANs, deep GPs) provides hierarchical feature extraction, handles very high-dimensional and temporal data, and has produced superior empirical performance in PHM, anomaly detection and RUL tasks

Practical limitations and cautions include high false alarm rates (especially for anomaly detection), computational cost and scalability, interpretability of deep models, and publication bias in semi-supervised claims; safe use of unlabeled data is not guaranteed without assumptions

Promising future opportunities for ML in reliability and safety: (1) uncertainty quantification and deployment; (2) fleet-level and system-of-systems PHM; (3) integration with accident databases and safety management systems; (4) ML with wearables/sensors for predictive safety analytics; (5) applying Deep Gaussian Processes and GANs for better uncertainty and generative modeling

Spacecraft anomaly detection evidence: OC-SVM and LSTM detect contextual anomalies beyond fixed-threshold alarms but reported high false positive rates, highlighting need for high precision for operational adoption

Conclusion: ML will continue to transform reliability and safety but realizing impact requires attention to uncertainty quantification, deployment considerations, scalability, interpretability, and the safety/reliability of ML systems themselves
